field.label: Research Interests
field.value: My research lies at the interface of the fields of health law, bioethics and the governance of medical research. I am interested in genetic discrimination in the area of personal insurance, employment and in the area of immigration and have successfully developed multiple research projects on these issues.

bilingual.french: Ma recherche se situe à l’intersection des domaines du droit de la santé, de la bioéthique et de la gouvernance de la recherche médicale. Je suis actuellement financé par le Commissariat à la vie privée du Canada sur un projet qui répond aux défis de l’utilisation de l’informatique en nuage pour la recherche avec des données génomiques. Je suis également financé par plusieurs projets scientifiques (ex. PRE-THERA, OPTI-THERA, ICGC) pour effectuer des recherches sur les cadres juridiques et éthiques de gouvernance applicable à la médecine personnalisée. Depuis 2004, je me suis intéressée à la question de la discrimination génétique dans les contextes de l’assurance de personnes et de l'immigration à travers plusieurs projets de recherche.
bilingual.english: My research lies at the interface of the fields of health law, bioethics and the governance of medical research. I am interested in genetic discrimination in the area of personal insurance, employment and in the area of immigration and have successfully developed multiple research projects on these issues.

Funding Title
field.value: Multidimensional Epigenomics Mapping Centre (EMC) at McGill

field.label: Project Description
field.value: To join global efforts (The International Human Epigenome Consortium) we will establish an Epigenome Mapping Centre (EMC) at McGill University that builds upon a high-throughput sequencing infrastructure with a critical mass of expertise and technology available to contribute significantly in deciphering the functional code of the human genome. Our work is internationally coordinated and will support research initiatives across the Canadian research community. We apply epigenome mapping to understand interactions between environment and genome in human blood cells, to interpret diseases impacting metabolism using tissue samples and to study how epigenetic changes can alter function of the brain. EMC McGill is a national hub housing a critical mass of epigenomics expertise supported by state-of-the-art genomics infrastructure. Our integrated operation also includes a legal and ethics component. It will contribute to Canadian leadership in epigenome research in biomedicine.

bilingual.english: To join global efforts (The International Human Epigenome Consortium) we will establish an Epigenome Mapping Centre (EMC) at McGill University that builds upon a high-throughput sequencing infrastructure with a critical mass of expertise and technology available to contribute significantly in deciphering the functional code of the human genome. Our work is internationally coordinated and will support research initiatives across the Canadian research community. We apply epigenome mapping to understand interactions between environment and genome in human blood cells, to interpret diseases impacting metabolism using tissue samples and to study how epigenetic changes can alter function of the brain. EMC McGill is a national hub housing a critical mass of epigenomics expertise supported by state-of-the-art genomics infrastructure. Our integrated operation also includes a legal and ethics component. It will contribute to Canadian leadership in epigenome research in biomedicine.

Funding Title
field.value: Epigenomics Secure Data Sharing Platform for Integrative Analyses (EpiShare)

field.label: Project Description
field.value: Advances in next-generation sequencing have ledto a vast increase in available human epigenetic data, including transcriptomicdata (via RNA-seq) and chromatin data (via ChIP-seq). These epigenetic datasetshave led to the development of expression-wide association studies (EWAS) andchromatin-wide association studies (CWAS). These approaches may lead toimproved biomedical applications by providing mechanistic explanations and keyinsights into the interpretation of genome-wide association studies (GWAS).However, one of the main issues for users of these datasets is that obtainingthe raw data stored at multiple controlled access repositories can be a verychallenging task. That is because access to this raw data needs to becontrolled in order to protect research participants’ right to privacy.

These approaches may lead toimproved biomedical applications by providing mechanistic explanations and keyinsights into the interpretation of genome-wide association studies (GWAS).However, one of the main issues for users of these datasets is that obtainingthe raw data stored at multiple controlled access repositories can be a verychallenging task. That is because access to this raw data needs to becontrolled in order to protect research participants’ right to privacy.

Funding Title
field.value: Can DIG: Canadian Distributed cyber-Infrastructure for Genomics

field.label: Project Description
field.value: This project is divided into four activities.1: Develop a broad Canadian data sharing framework, using the APIs that we and others are developing under the auspices of the Global Alliance forGenomics and Health (GA4GH); 2: continue the development of GenAP: a computational gateway for data analysis in life sciences that isconfigured to take advantage of Compute Canada infrastructure; 3: build a data-sharing platform that will allow for the collection of standardized clinical data, dynamic definition of cohorts, and performance of genome analytics across datasets that are being stored on various Compute Canada nodes; and, 4: to enable genome-guided clinical trials across Canada, establish the Canadian Molecular Profiling in Cancer Trials (CAMPACT) Interchange. Together, the four Activities will utilize Compute Canada infrastructure to build a distributed and secure computational framework for the analysis of genomic data sets relevant to human diseases and beyond.

bilingual.english: This project is divided into four activities.1: Develop a broad Canadian data sharing framework, using the APIs that we and others are developing under the auspices of the Global Alliance forGenomics and Health (GA4GH); 2: continue the development of GenAP: a computational gateway for data analysis in life sciences that isconfigured to take advantage of Compute Canada infrastructure; 3: build a data-sharing platform that will allow for the collection of standardized clinical data, dynamic definition of cohorts, and performance of genome analytics across datasets that are being stored on various Compute Canada nodes; and, 4: to enable genome-guided clinical trials across Canada, establish the Canadian Molecular Profiling in Cancer Trials (CAMPACT) Interchange. Together, the four Activities will utilize Compute Canada infrastructure to build a distributed and secure computational framework for the analysis of genomic data sets relevant to human diseases and beyond.

Funding Title
field.value: A Syst-OMICS Approach to Ensuring Food Safety and Reducing the Economic Burden of Salmonellosis

field.label: Project Description
field.value: Each year, approximately 88,000 people become sick from consuming fresh produce that is contaminated with Salmonella. An anticipatory governance approach will be used to conduct are gulatory assessment integrating a careful consideration of the evidentiary requirements, the economic, legal, ethical, regulatory, and global policy constraints as well as the trade implications of supporting such a paradigm shift. More precisely, the CGP team will: 1) assess the viability and implementability of a novel genomic test for Salmonella that can determine the pathogenic status of a given isolate; and 2)assess the need to shift to a risk-based approach to food safety that classifies food borne microbial adulterants on the basis of their pathogenicity,in contrast to the current regulatory practice of classifying a microbial adulterant based on species determination alone.

bilingual.english: Each year, approximately 88,000 people become sick from consuming fresh produce that is contaminated with Salmonella. An anticipatory governance approach will be used to conduct are gulatory assessment integrating a careful consideration of the evidentiary requirements, the economic, legal, ethical, regulatory, and global policy constraints as well as the trade implications of supporting such a paradigm shift. More precisely, the CGP team will: 1) assess the viability and implementability of a novel genomic test for Salmonella that can determine the pathogenic status of a given isolate; and 2)assess the need to shift to a risk-based approach to food safety that classifies food borne microbial adulterants on the basis of their pathogenicity,in contrast to the current regulatory practice of classifying a microbial adulterant based on species determination alone.

Funding Title
field.value: Médecine personnalisée, biobanques et recherche translationelle : élaboration d’un cadre de gouvernance pour le bénéfice des Québécois

field.label: Project Description
field.value: La médecine personnalisée est une approche thérapeutique de rupture considérée comme une des applications les plus prometteuses des recherches effectuées dans le domaine de la génomique & des autres sciences «OMIQUES». Un nouveau type d’infrastructures a récemment été développé, portant sur des catégories de maladies spécifiques & ayant une vocation translationnelle encore plus près de la clinique (ex. Q-CROC, la biobanque de la Cohorte hospitalière de l’ICM & l’Hepatopancreatobiliary (HPB) & Transplant Research Biobank at McGill). Ces infrastructures permettent de faire de la recherche, de suivre les patients en temps réel & de les informer des découvertes ou opportunités thérapeutiques applicables à leur profil génétique particulier. Ce programme de recherche a comme objectif de définir les politiques juridiques & éthiques nécessaires à l’établissement d’infrastructures de recherche translationelle optimales, sécuritaires & centrées sur le patient en médecine personnalisée au Qc.

bilingual.english: La médecine personnalisée est une approche thérapeutique de rupture considérée comme une des applications les plus prometteuses des recherches effectuées dans le domaine de la génomique & des autres sciences «OMIQUES». Un nouveau type d’infrastructures a récemment été développé, portant sur des catégories de maladies spécifiques & ayant une vocation translationnelle encore plus près de la clinique (ex. Q-CROC, la biobanque de la Cohorte hospitalière de l’ICM & l’Hepatopancreatobiliary (HPB) & Transplant Research Biobank at McGill). Ces infrastructures permettent de faire de la recherche, de suivre les patients en temps réel & de les informer des découvertes ou opportunités thérapeutiques applicables à leur profil génétique particulier. Ce programme de recherche a comme objectif de définir les politiques juridiques & éthiques nécessaires à l’établissement d’infrastructures de recherche translationelle optimales, sécuritaires & centrées sur le patient en médecine personnalisée au Qc.

Project Description
field.value: The RMGA is a network of multi- and trans-disciplinary researchers. Its objective is to support and develop basic and applied human genetic research by creating, managing, and promoting scientific infrastructures and knowledge transfer through health services and interventions, for the benefit of the Quebec population. The Network has close to 350 members, representing the majority of human genetics researchers in Quebec. The RMGA includes a Legal and Socio-Ethical Issues Infrastructure at the CGP that considers those issues arising from secondary use of biological materials and data in health research.

Its objective is to support and develop basic and applied human genetic research by creating, managing, and promoting scientific infrastructures and knowledge transfer through health services and interventions, for the benefit of the Quebec population. The Network has close to 350 members, representing the majority of human genetics researchers in Quebec. The RMGA includes a Legal and Socio-Ethical Issues Infrastructure at the CGP that considers those issues arising from secondary use of biological materials and data in health research.

Funding Title
field.value: The International Cancer Genome Consortium (ICGC) / Data Access Compliance Office (DACO)

field.label: Project Description
field.value: The Data Access Compliance Office (DACO) will handle requests for access to controlled data collected by the International Cancer Genome Consortium. It will report to both the Data Coordination Centre and the International Data Access Committee. It will consider requests for access to controlled data for projects in conformity with the goals and policies of ICGC. Thus request should include: the purpose and relevance of the research; the compatibility of the research; the protection of participants and security of data. DACO will maintain a file of each request to be updated in case of any significant change in the research protocol, addition of new researchers, links to new projects, etc.

Funding Title
field.value: Réseau en soins de santé personnalisés-Q-CROC

field.label: Project Description
field.value: This project aims to broaden and deepen the existing Q-CROC Network which has developed internationally recognized expertise in designing and executing biospy-driven studies to identify biomarkers in metastatic cancers. Moreover, it will use a program in which all new cancer patients are asked to consent to having their primary tumor biobanked and profiled, to having their entire clinical course anonymously recorded, and to being re-contacted for additional studies. Consistent with its prospective population-based approach, the new trans-national global network will help generate the large scale of profiled patient numbers and build an enormous biological and clinically annotated database.

bilingual.english: This project aims to broaden and deepen the existing Q-CROC Network which has developed internationally recognized expertise in designing and executing biospy-driven studies to identify biomarkers in metastatic cancers. Moreover, it will use a program in which all new cancer patients are asked to consent to having their primary tumor biobanked and profiled, to having their entire clinical course anonymously recorded, and to being re-contacted for additional studies. Consistent with its prospective population-based approach, the new trans-national global network will help generate the large scale of profiled patient numbers and build an enormous biological and clinically annotated database.

field.value: CE in Biomarker-Driven Clinical Research for Personalized Medicine in Cancer (EXACTIS)

field.label: Project Description
field.value: The Centre of Genomics and Policy will provide a review of the ethical and legal issues while ensuring that: 1) the consent form respects the federal and provincial legal requirements (on re-use of samples, governance, confidentiality, data-sharing, e-consent, risks, etc.); and 2) is compliant with the various ethical policies and guidelines pertaining to storage of data and sample, (access, re-contact). Finally, we will analyze, the legal liability of health professionals undertaking research.

Funding Title
field.value: Élaboration d’une stratégie de dissémination des connaissances sur les cancers familiaux dans le contexte des soins palliatifs fondée sur une analyse éthico-légale des points de vue des intervenants et des familles

field.label: Project Description
field.value: Considérant la nature familiale de nombreux types de cancer et les récents progrès dans le domaine de la génétique, incluant les domaines scientifiques connexes; il est particulièrement important de bien définir le cadre normatif applicable à la communication de l’historique familial de cancer aux membres de la famille des patients en soins palliatifs. Ce projet vise à identifier les balises juridiques et éthiques applicables à la communication de l’historique familial de cancer aux membres de la famille d’un patient en soins palliatifs. Les données obtenues par l’entremise d‘une étude de portée et de l’analyse du droit comparée seront réexaminées à la lumière des résultats obtenus dans les autres activités de recherche (entrevues et focus groups) du projet, ce qui permettra de mieux identifier les pistes de réforme pour améliorer les cadres juridique et normatif applicables à la communication de l’historique familial de cancer aux membres de la famille depatients en soins palliatifs.

Ce projet vise à identifier les balises juridiques et éthiques applicables à la communication de l’historique familial de cancer aux membres de la famille d’un patient en soins palliatifs. Funding Title
field.value: Innovative Chemogenomic Tools to Improve Outcome in Acute Myeloid Leukemia

field.label: Project Description
field.value: This project intends to implement two novel tests in the healthcare system: 1) a chemogenomic model for the development of a prognostic test in Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML); and 2) an integrated detection kit for Minimal Residual Disease (MRD). Our first objective is to highlight the strengths and weaknesses of Canadian federal and provincial regulatory test approval models. To this end, we will undertake a comparative analysis of US and EU models. Our second objective is to develop recommendations based on an ethical and legal analysis of the duty to inform in the context of labl directors (i.e., whether these directors are under an obligation to inform treating physicians of clinically-valuable information resulting from AML research).

To this end, we will undertake a comparative analysis of US and EU models. Our second objective is to develop recommendations based on an ethical and legal analysis of the duty to inform in the context of labl directors (i.e., whether these directors are under an obligation to inform treating physicians of clinically-valuable information resulting from AML research).

Funding Title
field.value: Personalized Risk Stratification for the Prevention and Early Detection of Breast Cancer (PERSPECTIVE)

field.label: Project Description
field.value: Designed to significantly extend the benefits of the current high-quality population screening program, particularly for younger women (25 to 49) by implementing a risk stratification approach targeting screening at an identifiable subset of women with relatively high risk of breast cancer (BC) who are missed by the current standard age-based screening program. This personalized risk-based approach to breast cancer screening will detect cancers at an earlier stage. Knowledge of the genetic basis of BC and its risk factors will allow stratification of individuals into different risk groups for screening and personalized follow-up with appropriate preventive and clinical measures. At the end of our project we will deliver a web-based risk stratification and communication toolbox for use by health professionals and women to facilitate the implementation of a personalized risk-based approach in BC screening and management.

This personalized risk-based approach to breast cancer screening will detect cancers at an earlier stage. Knowledge of the genetic basis of BC and its risk factors will allow stratification of individuals into different risk groups for screening and personalized follow-up with appropriate preventive and clinical measures. At the end of our project we will deliver a web-based risk stratification and communication toolbox for use by health professionals and women to facilitate the implementation of a personalized risk-based approach in BC screening and management.

Funding Title
field.value: Pistes de réformes législatives en matière de parrainage familial : un consensus à établir sur les tests d’ADN dans les dossiers d’immigration

field.label: Project Description
field.value: In Canada, Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) representatives increasingly resort to DNA testing to confirm biological filiations in the realm of immigration sponsorship possibly leading to genetic discrimination as documented in Canadian case law. In collaboration with the Canadian Council for Refugees and Immigration Canada, this project proposes a multidisciplinary analysis (qualitative research, systematic review, and consensus conference) to: 1) determine the social, cultural, and ethical issues associated with the use of DNA testing in the family sponsorship process; and 2) propose a legislative and political reform in response to this emerging problematic.

Funding Title
field.value: Framework for Decision-Making for Rare Diseases

field.label: Project Description
field.value: As our understanding of diseases and how to treat them evolves, so too must our decision making procedures for providing fair and cost effective treatments for those living with an illness. Today, one area of policy and decision making in particular lags behind, that for treating rare diseases. At present there is no policy framework to help decision makers navigate the complex factors involved when making decisions about paying for orphan drugs. This project brings together a multidisciplinary team of experts in matters relating to treatment for rare diseases, and will incorporate input from the public and key stakeholders to develop such a framework. It will facilitate priority setting for orphan treatment decisions constrained by a limited budget, that considers the relevant developmental, clinical and economic factors and ethical principles, as well as being consistent with the values of society at large.

bilingual.english: As our understanding of diseases and how to treat them evolves, so too must our decision making procedures for providing fair and cost effective treatments for those living with an illness. Today, one area of policy and decision making in particular lags behind, that for treating rare diseases. At present there is no policy framework to help decision makers navigate the complex factors involved when making decisions about paying for orphan drugs. This project brings together a multidisciplinary team of experts in matters relating to treatment for rare diseases, and will incorporate input from the public and key stakeholders to develop such a framework. It will facilitate priority setting for orphan treatment decisions constrained by a limited budget, that considers the relevant developmental, clinical and economic factors and ethical principles, as well as being consistent with the values of society at large.

Funding Title
field.value: Harmonizing Privacy Laws to Enable International Biobank Research

field.label: Project Description
field.value: Aims to compare and analyze national & int'l privacy frameworks applicable to genomic databases and biobanks. Series of articles prepared on the privacy frameworks in place in a wide sample of countries and regions. Each art. will survey the privacy instruments & legal & policy materials in place in a given jurisdiction, and will provide a legal analysis & critical evaluation of those instruments and materials. The general political & research contexts of the country or region will be introduced, and a description of its biobanking ecosystem will be provided. This will be followed by a comprehensive description of the legal & regulatory privacy framework applicable to genomic databases/biobanks in the country or region. Int'l Advisory Board consisting of three internationally recognized scholars to provide oversight and guidance of the project throughout its development and advancement. Series of articles published in 2 dedicated special issues in the Journal of Law, Medicine & Ethics.

Funding Title
field.value: Integrative Epigenomic Data Coordination Centre (EDCC) at McGill

field.label: Project Description
field.value: This project proposes an integrative Epigenomic Data Coordination Centre (EDCC) at McGill, which will be a national hub to support data collection, processing, storage and dissemination for projects funded under the CEEHRC initiative and facilitate integration with the IHEC. The outcome will include data pipelines and tools using standardized formats and vocabularies for verification, validation, and analyses across the CEEHRC network. The EDCC McGill will also develop a framework that leverages Compute Canada national resources to support large-scale processing, sharing and visualization of epigenomics data. The platform will enable epigenetic researchers on a national level to query and exploit this valuable resource.

bilingual.english: This project proposes an integrative Epigenomic Data Coordination Centre (EDCC) at McGill, which will be a national hub to support data collection, processing, storage and dissemination for projects funded under the CEEHRC initiative and facilitate integration with the IHEC. The outcome will include data pipelines and tools using standardized formats and vocabularies for verification, validation, and analyses across the CEEHRC network. The EDCC McGill will also develop a framework that leverages Compute Canada national resources to support large-scale processing, sharing and visualization of epigenomics data. The platform will enable epigenetic researchers on a national level to query and exploit this valuable resource.

Funding Title
field.value: Optimisation des approches thérapeutiques en soins personnalisés de première ligne (OPTI-THERA)

field.label: Project Description
field.value: The Centre of Genomics and Policy will conduct research concerning: 1) the legal aspects surrounding insurance and the use of genetic information; 2) the role of a trusted third party; 3) the conflict of interest issues in public-private partnerships for personalized medicine. Collaborating closely on this project, the Population Project in Genomics and Society (P3G) will: 1) review and amend of the project's consent forms; 2) provide ongoing ethics support (i.e., ethics approval); and 3) develop policies and procedures (re. clinical assessment and gate keeping functions).

Funding Title
field.value: From Biobanking to International Governance: Fostering Innovation in Stem Cell Research

field.label: Project Description
field.value: This team will examine the current national and international stem cell banking landscape against the biobanking models for human tissues generally, with a view to evaluate existing governance, commercialization and regulatory frameworks and to propose policy recommendations. This project will increase understanding of the factors which encourage or hinder stem cell translation by looking at ethical, legal, social and commercialization issues surrounding stem cell banks throughout the entire research cycle (from banking and distribution to derivation and use). The team will develop “international governance models” and a “Points to Consider” thereby providing a wide range of stakeholders and receptors (e.g. researchers, stem cell bankers, policy-makers and the general public), with analyses, strategies and solutions for moving towards translational stem cell research within Canada and on the global stage.

Funding Title
field.value: Access to Health Insurance in the Context of Personalized Medicine

field.label: Project Description
field.value: The Personalized Medicine Partnership for Cancer (PMPC) projects, lead by Caprion Proteome, are expected to have a measurable impact on clinical diagnosis and therapeutic management of various cancers as well as on the efficiency and costs of the healthcare system by developing an integrated clinical platform to validate new biomarkers, develop new diagnostic tests as well as improved therapies. The CGP is leading the sub-project "Insurance and personalized medicine", which aims to account for the legislative, regulatory, and normative changes needed to maximize societal benefits related to the use of genetic data in clinical cancer research in Quebec. Our main objectives include: 1) analyzing the normative insurance framework in Quebec; 2) reviewing insurance proposition form requirements; and 3) analyzing consent forms (for diagnostic tests in clinical and research contexts).

The CGP is leading the sub-project "Insurance and personalized medicine", which aims to account for the legislative, regulatory, and normative changes needed to maximize societal benefits related to the use of genetic data in clinical cancer research in Quebec. Our main objectives include: 1) analyzing the normative insurance framework in Quebec; 2) reviewing insurance proposition form requirements; and 3) analyzing consent forms (for diagnostic tests in clinical and research contexts).

Funding Title
field.value: Réconcilier le droit et l'éthique avec la science ouverte dans la recherche biotechnologique en santé : l'exemple du consentement aux banques de données ouvertes

field.label: Project Description
field.value: Our research will investigate the impact of open biotechnology on research ethics and legal policies with a particular focus placed on informed consent (scope of consent, privacy, data ownership) to large open database projects. We will use a combination of quantitative and qualitative research strategies that will offer complementary applied legal and ethical data on the impact of open biotechnology on the governance of genomic research. The use of a common research methodology in all streams of the project will facilitate comparisons and integration of our results. Our methods will include comparative legal and ethical research (policy review, legal research), questionnaire analysis and focus group interviews. To validate our findings, we will engage stakeholders at the annual meetings of two major organizations involved in research with open databases: The Public Population Project in Genomics (P3G) and the International Cancer Genome Consortium (ICGC).

The use of a common research methodology in all streams of the project will facilitate comparisons and integration of our results. Our methods will include comparative legal and ethical research (policy review, legal research), questionnaire analysis and focus group interviews. To validate our findings, we will engage stakeholders at the annual meetings of two major organizations involved in research with open databases: The Public Population Project in Genomics (P3G) and the International Cancer Genome Consortium (ICGC).

Funding Title
field.value: Translation Challenges, Science Policy and Stem Cell Research

field.label: Project Description
field.value: Intellectual property (IP) is perceived as playing an important role in the commercialization process, and the role of patents in particular has received a considerable amount of attention in the literature (Golden 2010). Our focus in this phase will be on the relationship between translation and commercialization pressure (including IP policies), and data access policies. We will investigate current restrictions to access, as reflected in (for example)international stem cell banking policies, including restrictions to future IP claims, and compare them with existing open access policies (e.g., UK Stem Cell Initiative and the CIRM iPS biobank). This work will include an analysis of whether certain commercialization policies, and concomitant IP approaches (such as restrictive patenting practices) do in fact conflict with emerging open access approaches and policies, as reflected, for example, in the UK Stem Cell Bank (Joly 2010; George 2010).

We will investigate current restrictions to access, as reflected in (for example)international stem cell banking policies, including restrictions to future IP claims, and compare them with existing open access policies (e.g., UK Stem Cell Initiative and the CIRM iPS biobank). This work will include an analysis of whether certain commercialization policies, and concomitant IP approaches (such as restrictive patenting practices) do in fact conflict with emerging open access approaches and policies, as reflected, for example, in the UK Stem Cell Bank (Joly 2010; George 2010).

Funding Title
field.value: CIHR Team of Prediction and Communication of Familial Risks of Breast Cancer (INHERIT)

field.label: Project Description
field.value: The overarching goal of this project is to thoroughly evaluate the prediction of breast cancer risk and its communication to individuals with a family history of breast cancer. This program is identifying specific genetic factors contributing to breast cancer susceptibility, in particular, yet poorly explored, uncommon or rare intermediate-risk variants that potentially explain a significant proportion of missing familial risk of breast cancer. Some of these could enter clinical cancer genetics practice in the foreseeable future.

Funding Title
field.value: Towards Systems Medicine of Fatty Liver Disease

field.label: Project Description
field.value: This project focuses on three questions relating to a disease-specific biobank: 1) Given its current ethical framework, can the liver biobank re-contact research participants for updates to enrich the quality of the bank? If so, what measures will need to be taken to meet Canadian and international ethical standards? 2) How can a policy to return incidental findings be developed that takes advantage of a double-coding system of privacy protection but is streamlined and efficient? 3) What is the scientific, ethical, legal, and policy framework applicable to the return of results in the context of a personalized medicine biobank project?

Funding Title
field.value: Applied Metagenomics of the Watershed Microbiome

field.label: Project Description
field.value: Metagenomics is a “culture-independent” method for analysis of multiple microbial genomes. Importantly, water safety and genomics together create a highly volatile postgenomics innovation trajectory for metagenomics applications in public health and ecosystem health.This study comprises three stages. First, we will identify the metagenomics stakeholders for water safety in consultation with the water and metagenomics experts and through metagenomics and water safety document analyses and interviews. Second, the issues associated with a new watershed test that may impact each stakeholder group will be identified through complementary social science methodologies including document analyses, literature reviews, surveys, focus groups and interviews. Third, we will hold a multi-stakeholder workshop to present, negotiate and validate the identified social, legal, ethical and policy issues in the form of a “points-to-consider” document to inform prospective policy.

bilingual.english: Metagenomics is a “culture-independent” method for analysis of multiple microbial genomes. Importantly, water safety and genomics together create a highly volatile postgenomics innovation trajectory for metagenomics applications in public health and ecosystem health.This study comprises three stages. Second, the issues associated with a new watershed test that may impact each stakeholder group will be identified through complementary social science methodologies including document analyses, literature reviews, surveys, focus groups and interviews. Third, we will hold a multi-stakeholder workshop to present, negotiate and validate the identified social, legal, ethical and policy issues in the form of a “points-to-consider” document to inform prospective policy.

Funding Title
field.value: Susceptibilité génétique au cancer du sein : Identification, prediction et communication

field.label: Project Description
field.value: The rules and policies of collaborative oncological gene-environment studies (COGS) as well as the laws and public policies applicable to the international exchange of genetic samples will be identified and analyzed by this project.Findings will be validated by consultation with experts from each of the selected countries or regions. Our analysis, complemented by a critical literature review, will allow us to outline the central similarities and differences between norms and produce recommendations aiming to harmonize the rules of EI-RFCS with those of COGS. Our second objective concerns the communication of information to third parties. We will carry out a review of the relevant law, regulations, and guidelines concerning medical liability and genetic discrimination in Quebec. The contextual legal analysis of these issues will serve to identify those elements that would benefit from the issuance of recommendations addressing medical liability and genetic discrimination in Quebec.

field.value: Canadian Genetics and Life Insurance Task Force

bilingual.english: Research on Genetic Discrimination (GD)

field.label: Description / Contribution Value/Impact
field.value: I began my research in the field of GD in 2003 as the Coordinator of the Canadian Working Group on Genetic and Life Insurance. This pan-Canadian multidisciplinary group released recommendations that were published in the Canadian Medical Association Journal. In the next few years I continued advancing my research program in this field which lead me to collaborate very closely with the Council of Europe’s on their work on the topic. In early 2013, I published the first international systematic review of documented cases of GD in the field of life insurance, in BMC Medicine and in 2014 I developed the first international recommendation regarding GD in the fast growing field of personalized medicine. I testified in front of the Canadian Senate on the potential adoption of Bill S-201, An Act to prohibit and prevent GD in 2014. I was asked to comment on its objectives and content on several radio shows and television programs (the Walrus, the Globe and Mail, etc.) in 2015 and 2016.

bilingual.english: I began my research in the field of GD in 2003 as the Coordinator of the Canadian Working Group on Genetic and Life Insurance. This pan-Canadian multidisciplinary group released recommendations that were published in the Canadian Medical Association Journal. In the next few years I continued advancing my research program in this field which lead me to collaborate very closely with the Council of Europe’s on their work on the topic. In early 2013, I published the first international systematic review of documented cases of GD in the field of life insurance, in BMC Medicine and in 2014 I developed the first international recommendation regarding GD in the fast growing field of personalized medicine. I testified in front of the Canadian Senate on the potential adoption of Bill S-201, An Act to prohibit and prevent GD in 2014. I was asked to comment on its objectives and content on several radio shows and television programs (the Walrus, the Globe and Mail, etc.) in 2015 and 2016.
Controlled Access to Genetic Data

field.label: Description / Contribution Value/Impact
field.value: Sharing genomic data among researchers is a precondition for translating discoveries into personalized health care. To promote responsible sharing, the "controlled access" mechanism was proposed. I had a central role in the research, development and successful implementation of controlled access mechanisms for two large academic consortia in the field of genomics: The International Cancer Genome Consortium (ICGC) and the International Human Epigenome Consortium (IHEC). These mechanisms are now used by emerging organizations and consortia as models. This research has allowed me to obtain funding (CIHR, Genome Canada and Ontario Institute of Cancer Research) and has been the topic of numerous publications and conferences. It has also been recognized, in 2012, by the “Innovation Merit" award of the Quebec Bar.

bilingual.english: Sharing genomic data among researchers is a precondition for translating discoveries into personalized health care. To promote responsible sharing, the "controlled access" mechanism was proposed. I had a central role in the research, development and successful implementation of controlled access mechanisms for two large academic consortia in the field of genomics: The International Cancer Genome Consortium (ICGC) and the International Human Epigenome Consortium (IHEC). These mechanisms are now used by emerging organizations and consortia as models. This research has allowed me to obtain funding (CIHR, Genome Canada and Ontario Institute of Cancer Research) and has been the topic of numerous publications and conferences. It has also been recognized, in 2012, by the “Innovation Merit" award of the Quebec Bar.

field.label: Title
field.value: Editor of a Handbook on Medical Law and Ethics for Routledge

bilingual.english: Editor of a Handbook on Medical Law and Ethics for Routledge

field.label: Description / Contribution Value/Impact
field.value: This Handbook is the culmination of two years of international, comparative research involving 37 authors from 12 countries. The use of a common template for addressing human rights issues, the impact of new technologies on health professionals, anticipatory governance as well as the challenges of the translational spectrum in genomics and its implications for public health, were analyzed. In addition to my editorial work with Knoppers on the book, I co-authored the introductory chapter and the chapter on the legal and ethical aspects of personalized medicine. The Handbook received very favorable reviews and was “Best pick of the month” of Amazon.com for February 2015.

bilingual.english: This Handbook is the culmination of two years of international, comparative research involving 37 authors from 12 countries. The use of a common template for addressing human rights issues, the impact of new technologies on health professionals, anticipatory governance as well as the challenges of the translational spectrum in genomics and its implications for public health, were analyzed. In addition to my editorial work with Knoppers on the book, I co-authored the introductory chapter and the chapter on the legal and ethical aspects of personalized medicine. The Handbook received very favorable reviews and was “Best pick of the month” of Amazon.com for February 2015.
